channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 The New York Times Company

item.title: Live Updates: A Year After Hamas Attack, Israelis and Palestinians Reflect on Loss
item.description: Israelis are gathering to remember those killed and abducted last Oct. 7. For Palestinians in Gaza, there is no reprieve from a war that has killed tens of thousands.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times

item.title: Live Updates: Israel Mounts Heavy Attack on Southern Lebanon
item.description: After days of attacks there, Israel carried out further strikes in Lebanon and said it was sending more troops to fight Hezbollah. It also struck in Gaza to destroy a rocket launcher that Hamas used to target Tel Aviv.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine Is Awarded to Victor Ambros and Gary Ruvkun
item.description: The prize was awarded for their discovery of microRNA, which helps determine how cells develop and function.
item.dc:creator: Teddy Rosenbluth and Derrick Bryson Taylor
item.media:description: Thomas Perlmann, the secretary general of the Nobel Committee, announcing the winners at the Karolinska Institute in Stockholm on Monday.

item.title: Fighting Myanmar’s Patriarchy, One All-Male Panel at a Time
item.description: Ying Lao has called out the pro-democracy movement for its frequent “manels,” arguing that the exclusion of women from such discussions is hurting the cause.
item.dc:creator: Verena Hölzl
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:credit: Lauren DeCicca for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ying Lao has long worked for democratic and feminist causes, but she has faced a backlash for her public evisceration of manels, or all-male panels.

item.title: China Calls for Tighter Security After Workers Are Killed in Pakistan
item.description: Two Chinese nationals were killed and another was injured after a convoy was attacked in Karachi on Sunday. A separatist group claimed responsibility.
item.dc:creator: Salman Masood
item.media:description: The site of an explosion outside Karachi airport, Pakistan, early Monday.

item.title: Ex-Philippine President, Under Investigation for War on Drugs, Returns to Politics
item.description: Rodrigo Duterte, who retired in 2022 after a six-year term as president, filed papers to run for mayor of Davao, his family’s political stronghold.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Francis R. Malasig
item.media:description: Rodrigo Duterte, in white mask, attending the inauguration of President Ferdinand Marcos Jr. of the Philippines, left, in Manila in 2022.

item.title: Russia Sentences 72-Year-Old American on Charges of Fighting for Ukraine
item.description: Stephen James Hubbard, a native of Big Rapids, Mich., whose family says is an English teacher, was sentenced to six years and 10 months in a penal colony.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: A still image taken from a video provided by the Moscow City Court of Stephen James Hubbard at a court hearing in Moscow on Monday.

item.title: A Hostage Waits for Her Husband Still Being Held in Gaza
item.description: A year after their home in Israel was torched and her family was taken by attackers on Oct. 7, a wife and mother clings to the hope that her husband might still come home alive.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sharon Cunio, her husband and their 4-year-old twin daughters were among the roughly 250 hostages abducted by Hamas on Oct. 7, 2023.

item.title: How Gaza Became a Mass Death Trap
item.description: Hundreds of thousands of civilians have been prevented from fleeing the narrow strip of land even as bombs have rained down, famine has loomed and disease has spread.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
United Nations Relief and Works Agency
item.media:credit: Samar Abu Elouf for The New York Times
item.media:description: A camp for internally displaced people in Khan Younis, southern Gaza, in late October 2023.

item.title: The War That Won’t End: How Oct. 7 Sparked a Year of Conflict
item.description: As war in the Middle East spreads, the original conflict between Israel and Hamas has persisted. This is why.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley, Ronen Bergman and Bilal Shbair
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: Palestinians entering Israel through a breach in the Gaza border fence during the Oct. 7 Hamas-led attacks.

item.title: Israel-Gaza War: Photos that Defined a Year of Conflict
item.description: Seven New York Times photojournalists describe moments that have defined a year of war.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times

item.title: A Hundred Years’ War for Our Time
item.description: Peace in the Middle East seems more elusive than ever, with Oct. 7 setting off a battle over not just land but the narrative itself.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: Relatives and friends of victims of the Oct. 7 attacks gathered at the site of the Nova music festival on the morning of the anniversary.

item.title: Climate Change Is Scorching Stretches of the Amazon River in Brazil
item.description: As a punishing drought dries up stretches of the Amazon River, Brazil is resorting to dredging to try to keep food, medicine and people flowing along the watery superhighway.
item.dc:creator: Ana Ionova
item.media:description: A much-depleted tributary of the Amazon, the Parana do Manaquiri, last month in Amazonas State, Brazil.

item.title: Tunisia’s Autocratic Leader Is Poised to Steamroll to Election Victory
item.description: President Kais Saied, who has jailed opponents and consolidated power, is almost certain to win Sunday’s election in the North African country, the birthplace of the Arab Spring movement.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.media:description: A poster for President Kais Saied on a building last month in Tunis. The president’s election opponents have largely either been jailed or disqualified.

item.title: Key Moments in the Middle East War Since Hamas’s Oct. 7 Attack on Israel: Timeline
item.description: Hamas’s Oct. 7 attack on Israel and the 12 months of conflagration that has followed.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: Victims lie on a highway in the Sderot area of southern Israel following the attack by Hamas on Oct. 7.

item.title: Hostages’ Families Endure Surreal Wait on Anniversary of Oct. 7 Attacks
item.description: More than 60 living hostages, and the bodies of about 35 others who are believed to be dead, are still in Gaza, according to the Israeli authorities.
item.dc:creator: Liam Stack
item.media:description: “I feel the hostage situation has been put to the back,” said Ofri Bibas-Levy, Yarden Bibas’s sister.

item.title: Palestinians in Gaza Reflect on One Year of Israel’s War With Hamas
item.description: The war has killed tens of thousands and devastated entire cities, leaving many in Gaza without a home and fueling a humanitarian catastrophe.
item.dc:creator: Bilal Shbair and Hiba Yazbek
item.media:credit: Yousef Masoud for The New York Times
item.media:description: Palestinians fleeing Israeli bombing in Khan Younis, southern Gaza, last year.

item.title: On the Oct. 7 Anniversary, Remembering the Nova Festival Victims
item.description: After hearing the dance track that was playing a year ago when the Hamas-led assault began, the hundreds who had gathered stood for a minute of silence, broken by a bereaved mother’s cries.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: Relatives and friends gathering at the site of the Nova music festival near Re’im, Israel, on Monday.

item.title: How Can I Cut PFAS ‘Forever Chemicals?’
item.description: They’re almost everywhere. And they’re bad. But there are some things you can do to avoid them.
item.dc:creator: Hiroko Tabuchi

item.title: Climbers Rescued from Himalayan Mountain After Being Stranded for Two Nights
item.description: The two women, one American and one British, became stranded on a Himalayan mountain when their food and equipment fell into a ravine, Indian officials said.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang

item.title: Israel Steps Up Attacks in Gaza and Lebanon Ahead of Oct. 7 Anniversary
item.description: Israel appeared to label much of northern Gaza as an evacuation zone and in Lebanon, Israeli airstrikes targeted Hezbollah strongholds, as the region also braced for Israel to hit back at Iran.
item.dc:creator: Adam Rasgon, Isabel Kershner and Norimitsu Onishi
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Israeli airstrikes targeting the southern suburbs of Beirut on Sunday.

item.title: Monday Briefing: Reflecting on a Year of War
item.description: Plus, Paris Fashion Week’s closing fantasia.
item.dc:creator: Gaya Gupta
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: A memorial near Re’im, Israel, in September.

item.title: Pakistan Bans Protest Movement in Renewed Crackdown on Dissent
item.description: Analysts say the military is expanding its efforts to squash opposition.
item.dc:creator: Zia ur-Rehman

item.title: Peter Jay, Headline-Making British Ambassador to the U.S., Dies at 87
item.description: His appointment sparked criticism and charges of nepotism. He later achieved unwanted attention as a character in the novel “Heartburn.”
item.dc:creator: Adam Nossiter
item.media:description: Peter Jay at his home in London in May 1977, shortly after being named British ambassador to the United States.

item.title: On Social Media, Gazans Share Advice for Those Under Fire in Lebanon
item.description: A woman known as Chef Hala, who has had to evacuate three times since Israel invaded Gaza, is among those offering practical tips and messages of solidarity.
item.dc:creator: Rawan Sheikh Ahmad and Aryn Baker

item.title: Pope Names 21 New Cardinals, Reaching Far Beyond Europe
item.description: The appointments cement Francis’ imprint on the group that will choose his successor, and reflect his vision of a more truly global Roman Catholic Church.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:description: Pope Francis read the list of new cardinals during his Sunday prayer at the Vatican. The ceremony to elevate them will take place next month.

item.title: U.K. Prime Minister’s Chief of Staff, Sue Gray, Resigns
item.description: Ms. Gray said intense media scrutiny of her role meant she “risked becoming a distraction” to the new Labour government.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Sue Gray last month at the meeting of the U.N. General Assembly in New York. In a statement on Sunday she said that “intense commentary around my position risked becoming a distraction to the government’s vital work of change.”

item.title: Fear Overshadows Oct. 7 Memorial Preparations in Israel
item.description: Amid the chaos and the war that followed the Hamas-led assault, Israel has not yet held a national day of mourning for the 1,200 people who were killed.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: A memorial near Re’im, Israel, in September.

item.title: Ship in Need of Repairs Has Explosive Cargo, but No Dock
item.description: The MV Ruby has meandered around Europe’s northwestern coastline under a cloud of suspicion over its thousands of tons of Russian fertilizer.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel
item.media:description: Damage to the Port of Beirut, in Lebanon, in 2020 after an explosion of 2,750 tons of ammonium nitrate. The MV Ruby may be carrying more than seven times as much.

item.title: How the Push to Avert a Broader War in Lebanon Fell Apart
item.description: Diplomats thought both Israel and Hezbollah supported a call for a temporary cease-fire. Then Israel killed Hezbollah’s leader.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard, Maria Abi-Habib, Michael D. Shear and Edward Wong
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: Portraits of Hassan Nasrallah amid the destruction from Israeli airstrikes in Dahiya, outside of Beirut.

item.title: What It’s Like to Return to Israeli Villages Attacked on Oct. 7
item.description: Along Israel’s border with Gaza, reminders of the trauma of the Hamas-led assault are inescapable as the few who have returned try to start anew.
item.dc:creator: Johnatan Reiss and Amit Elkayam
item.media:credit: Amit Elkayam for The New York Times.
item.media:description: More homes are turning their lights back on, signaling the gradual return of residents to the kibbutz.

item.title: As War in Ukraine Drags On, Dogs Offer Comfort
item.description: Dog ownership has surged over the past two years as people seek companionship. In Kyiv, Yorkies, poodles and bichons frisés now rule the streets.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut and Oleksandra Mykolyshyn
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dogs playing at the PesDay festival in Kyiv, Ukraine, in September. The event was a vivid illustration of the boom in dog ownership.

item.title: Israel Was Ready for a War With Hezbollah. Ending It Will Be Harder.
item.description: Lessons learned from a 2006 invasion of Lebanon have guided Israel in its current one. Security experts say a political deal is needed to restore calm.
item.dc:creator: Adam Rasgon
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: An Israeli unit in July 2006 firing along the front line in northern Israel during fighting with Hezbollah.

item.title: Israel Steps Up Attacks in Lebanon as Fighting Spreads
item.description: With the region on edge about a possible Israeli retaliatory strike on Iran, U.S. Central Command hit targets in Yemen, and Israel ordered evacuations in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Liam Stack, Victoria Kim and Andrew Jacobs
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Smoke rose on Saturday after Israeli airstrikes in southern Lebanon. Hezbollah on Saturday fired more rockets into northern Israel, though most seem to have been intercepted by Israel’s air-defense system.

item.title: Macron Calls for Halting Weapons to Israel for Gaza Conflict
item.description: The French leader’s comments drew the condemnation of Israel’s prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, and reflected the growing international concern over Israel’s expanding conflicts in the region.
item.dc:creator: Talya Minsberg
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron spoke on a French radio show on Saturday.

item.title: What to Know: How Israel Could Retaliate Against Iran
item.description: Iran has a number of sensitive sites, including oil infrastructure, military installations and nuclear facilities.
item.dc:creator: Lazaro Gamio and Eve Sampson

item.title: Fear Factors
item.description: Sometimes the scariest movies are the ones that depict the ordinary horrors of life.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: Ever-Shrinking Condos Are the Choice of Investors in Toronto and Vancouver
item.description: A new report shows that small condo units are preferred by investors and that a lack of investor buyers may now be delaying new buildings.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times
item.media:description: Small condos have become about a third of the market in Toronto over the last eight years.

item.title: As Israel Attacks, Many Lebanese Feel Dragged Into War
item.description: In a crisis-racked country where sectarian tensions simmer, many worry that the conflict between Israel and the Shiite militia Hezbollah will end in more destruction for all.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee and Hwaida Saad
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: Cleaning up on Monday after an early-morning Israeli airstrike on an apartment block in Beirut, Lebanon.

item.title: A Menace to Motorists, but the ‘Noble’ Moose Is Adopted by Newfoundland
item.description: Introduced to the island 120 years ago, moose are involved in hundreds of collisions each year. But the huge animal is an accepted part of life here. “I suspect that they got squatters’ rights.”
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen and Ian Willms
item.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times

item.title: Rwanda’s Doctors and Nurses Hit Hard by Deadly Marburg Virus
item.description: The Health Ministry has reported that 80 percent of the infected are health care professionals.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Hurtes and Arafat Mugabo
item.media:description: World Health Organization officials in Angola during a 2005 outbreak of the Marburg virus. The outbreak in Rwanda began in September, the country’s first encounter with the virus.

item.title: Michigan Father Dies in Israeli Airstrike in Lebanon, Family Says
item.description: Kamel Ahmad Jawad, a U.S. citizen, was remembered by friends and relatives as someone who chose to stay behind to help others who couldn’t flee.
item.dc:creator: Kate Selig
item.media:description: Smoke billowed after Israeli airstrikes in Nabatieh district, in southern Lebanon, in September.

item.title: Ukraine’s Donbas Strategy: Retreat Slowly and Maximize Russian Losses
item.description: The idea is to use rope-a-dope tactics, letting Russian forces pound away until they have exhausted themselves. It’s far from clear if the Ukrainian strategy will succeed.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Soldiers with an artillery battery of the 15th Brigade of the Ukrainian National Guard preparing to fire from their position in the Donbas region of Ukraine this week.

item.title: How a Nuclear Plant Is Dividing a Community in Poland
item.description: A plan to place American-made reactors on a picturesque coastline has broad support in Poland — and in Washington — but the geopolitical calculations have run into local opposition.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:credit: Maciek Nabrdalik for The New York Times
item.media:description: A harvest festival in Choczewo, Poland, where locals are bitterly divided on a plan for a proposed nuclear plant, Poland’s first.

item.title: Behind Trump’s Views on Ukraine: Putin’s Gambit and a Political Grudge
item.description: The roots of Donald Trump’s animus toward Ukraine — an issue with profound consequences should he be elected again — can be found in a yearlong series of events spanning 2016 and 2017.
item.dc:creator: Mark Mazzetti and Adam Entous
item.media:description: A meeting between President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia and former President Donald J. Trump in Hamburg in 2017 helps explain the roots of Mr. Trump’s often-disdainful attitude toward Ukraine.

item.title: Israel Targets Hezbollah as Khamenei, Iran’s Leader, Warns of Retaliation
item.description: Israel is drastically widening its fight against the Lebanese militant group that is backed by Iran, whose supreme leader said that “any strike on the Zionist regime is a service to humanity.”
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard, Euan Ward, Farnaz Fassihi, Victoria Kim and Michael Levenson
item.media:description: Smoke and flames rising after an Israeli airstrike in the Dahiyeh, area of Lebanon on Friday.

item.title: French Judge in Gisèle Pelicot Rape Trial Allows Video Evidence to Be Shown in Court
item.description: Gisèle Pelicot fought for the graphic videos made by her husband to be shown publicly in court, insisting they were essential evidence in a rape case against him and 50 other men.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter
item.media:description: Gisèle Pelicot leaving court in Avignon, France, on Wednesday. Her husband is accused of drugging her for years, and inviting strangers to their home to rape her.

item.title: US Conducts Strikes Against Houthis in Yemen
item.description: The Houthis have been attacking ships in the Red Sea in solidarity with Hamas, and the U.S. attacks were aimed at securing international waterways.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni and Ismaeel Naar
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Smoke rises after strikes on Houthi targets in Yemen.

item.title: Biden Cautions Israel on Plans to Retaliate Against Iran
item.description: The president suggested that Israel should consider alternative ways to retaliate against Iran.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs
item.media:description: President Biden joined his press secretary, Karine Jean-Pierre, left, at the daily press briefing Friday at the White House. It was the only time he has joined the briefing as president, and he took questions on the Middle East.

item.title: A Pentagon Debate: Are U.S. Deployments Containing the Fighting, or Inflaming It?
item.description: Military officials discuss whether sending more force to the Middle East is helping to prevent a much wider war, or emboldening Israel.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper and Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: K.C. Alfred/The San Diego Union-Tribune, via Associated Press
item.media:description: The aircraft carrier Abraham Lincoln and its strike group of destroyers and fighter squadrons has been monitoring Iran from the Gulf of Oman since August.

item.title: Iran’s Foreign Minister Conveys Support for Joint Cease-Fire in Lebanon and Gaza
item.description: Iran’s top diplomat appeared eager to convey Iran’s readiness to support a joint cease-fire in Lebanon and in Gaza — even as Iran’s supreme leader at home expressed readiness to fight Israel.
item.dc:creator: Alissa J. Rubin
item.media:description: Iran’s foreign minister, Abbas Araghchi, in Beirut, Lebanon, on Friday.

item.title: Russia and Syria Silent on Reported Strike Near Russian Base in Syria
item.description: A weapons facility near a Russian air base in a coastal Syrian city was destroyed on Thursday, according to a monitoring group.
item.dc:creator: Eve Sampson, Anton Troianovski, Aric Toler and Oleg Matsnev

item.title: Hamas Leader Is Holding Out for a Bigger War, U.S. Officials Say
item.description: Yahya Sinwar is increasingly fatalistic, has blocked a cease-fire deal and, so far, been frustrated that Hezbollah and Iran have not come to his aid, officials said.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes, Adam Goldman and Edward Wong
item.media:credit: Samar Abu Elouf for The New York Times
item.media:description: Yahya Sinwar, the leader of Hamas, in Gaza in April 2023. The group has shown no desire at all to engage in talks in recent weeks, U.S. officials say.

item.title: What Game Theory Tells Us About the Threat of an Israel-Iran War
item.description: Each side must predict how the other will react to avoid mutual destruction.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Destruction is seen in a Dahiya neighborhood south of Beirut after a week of deadly Israeli airstrikes.

item.title: Here Are the Hezbollah Leaders Israel Has Targeted
item.description: Israeli strikes have aimed to kill the leaders of the Lebanese militia, most recently Hashem Safieddine. It was not immediately clear whether he had been killed in an overnight strike near Beirut.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman and Lauren Leatherby

item.title: Champions League’s New Format Creates a New Reality
item.description: This year more than ever is showing that the competition means different things to different clubs. And that’s a good thing.
item.dc:creator: Rory Smith
item.media:description: Tiago Santos and Lille may already have their biggest win of the season.

item.title: Gender Identity Changes Must Be Recognized Across E.U. Borders, Court Rules
item.description: A man who changed his name and gender identity in Britain successfully challenged to have them legally recognized by Romania. “I’m representing everyone who is affected.”
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: The Pride Parade in Berlin in 2023. Rights campaigners say a court ruling may give transgender people more freedoms throughout the European Union.

item.title: Ayatollah Khamenei Praises Oct. 7 Attacks and Warns Israel in Rare Sermon
item.description: Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, who led Friday prayers for the first time in years, called for pan-Muslim unity against Israel and the United States at a memorial service for Hassan Nasrallah.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi and Leily Nikounazar
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tens of thousands of supporters gathered to hear Iran’s supreme leader, Ali Khamenei, lead Friday prayers in Tehran.

item.title: Bosnia Balkans flooding rains
item.description: A severe overnight rainstorm in the Balkans left several towns and villages flooded. Record summer temperatures had caused a drought that hampered the absorption of floodwaters.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel
item.media:description: Flooding on Friday after heavy rains in a village near the Bosnian town of Fojnica, about 30 miles west of Sarajevo.

item.title: Israel Expands Evacuation Warnings in Southern Lebanon After Renewed Strikes
item.description: Israeli soldiers were also waging a ground invasion in southern Lebanon targeting what military officials said were Hezbollah sites in the rugged border area.
item.dc:creator: Liam Stack
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: Smoke rising over the Dahiya area south of Beirut, in Lebanon, on Friday.

item.title: E.U. Court Says Some Rules for Soccer’s Transfer Market Are Illegal
item.description: A decision could force soccer’s governing body to rewrite the regulations that govern the sport’s multibillion-dollar transfer market.
item.dc:creator: Tariq Panja
item.media:description: Lassana Diarra, right, went to court after being fined millions of dollars for walking away from his contract and trying to join a new club.
